If a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originates (e.g. if they cross a mountain range or a river, or if they settle on a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, as opposed to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time, the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years, two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Spurs are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet might get caught in them.
If a rider falls off his horse and gets his foot caught in the stirrup, he can be dragged along if the horse runs. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
Firstly, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a narrow, smooth sole.
In addition, some saddles, particularly English saddles, have safety buckles that allow a stirrup leather to fall from the saddle when pulled backwards by a falling rider.

Downhill sports like skiing and snowboarding are popular sports in which you attach skis or a snowboard to your feet and slide down a snow-covered slope.

Japanese work culture is hierarchical and formal compared to what Westerners may be used to.
